pr_title: Created ClientLogger interface and its default implementation

timeline.message: Created ClientLogger interface and its default implementation as AndroidClientLogger that uses Android logging mechanisms. Modified all classes that used the logger to accept a given implementation or use the default one of nothing was provided.

This is probably not a useful log message. Thinking of the customer experience here, they don't really need to see a stack trace in logcat - this is just some validation that's happening in our pipeline. I would probably do two things:
1.) Construct the message as a string and simply log it at error level.
2.) Throw an HttpResponseException (RuntimeException here is no good) containing the same message.

replies.bodyText:
@bsiegel This came from the Java SDK where they check if the level has not been set or is greater than even error so nothing is logged. I guess I don't really know what customers would prefer is the default behavior, but I think we can stick with INFO like you propose :)
Maybe we could ask the Java folks why they chose this route as well.
replies.author: vcolin7

replies.bodyText:
Oh, it sounds like the solution for "don't log anything" is to set the level to NOT_SET (which is surprising to me - I would expect it to be called e.g. NONE).
On iOS we provide a ClientLoggers.none which is basically an implementation of the null object pattern - it's a ClientLogger which never actually logs anything.
I could go either way on this. I don't remember seeing other logging frameworks where you turn off logging by changing the verbosity level, that's why it surprised me. Would love to hear opinions from the peanut gallery.

For iOS we just truncated this application ID. Should we just do the same here? I don't feel like it's worth throwing an error.
Also, regardless of whether you change this or not, we should make the limitation clear in the doc comment on L157.

replies.bodyText: I stated this on a different comment, but I think we should determine how undesirable it would be to have an incomplete or incorrect Application ID to determine the course of action.
replies.author: vcolin7

replies.bodyText:
Yep, agreed. On iOS we have exactly the same problem, except worse because we accept the various options in the UserAgentPolicy initializer and most users don't expect constructors to throw exceptions.
One challenge is that for iOS we populate the applicationId as the bundle identifier if the user doesn't supply one. If the bundle identifier is > 24 characters, then the user will get an exception without ever doing anything related to the applicationId.
For Android I would think we'd want a similar default (probably group ID + artifact ID) for applicationId, so even though this isn't being set in a constructor, it'd still be surprising. Maybe let's chat with @adrianhall and see if he has some guidance.
